stem: A 52-year-old client is receiving a transfusion of packed red blood cells. Ten minutes into the infusion, the client reports severe lower back pain. Based on the information provided in the tabs, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: The client is experiencing an acute reaction during a packed red blood cell transfusion. The client reports severe lower back pain.
Background: The client is a 52-year-old, type AB positive, receiving a blood transfusion due to symptomatic anemia. The transfusion started at 14:00.
Assessment: At 14:10, the client became restless, diaphoretic, and reported 'tearing' pain in the lumbar region. Vital signs show a significant change from baseline: temperature increased to 100.4°F, heart rate increased to 132 bpm, and blood pressure decreased to 94/58 mmHg. Newly voided urine is dark-red/tea colored.
Recommendation: The blood transfusion has been stopped immediately. Maintain IV access with 0.9% normal saline. Notify the physician and blood bank immediately for further orders and evaluation.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: No lab values available. See Transfusion Record & Reaction Log for urine status.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: See Transfusion Record & Reaction Log for vital sign trends.

tabs.title: Adverse Event Protocol
tabs.content: Stop blood transfusion immediately. Disconnect the blood tubing. Maintain IV access with new tubing and 0.9% normal saline. Notify the physician and blood bank. Send the remaining blood and blood/urine samples to the laboratory.

actionOptions.text: Disconnect the blood tubing and initiate 0.9% normal saline with new tubing
Send a freshly collected urine specimen to the laboratory
Slow the rate of infusion to 50 mL/hr and continue monitoring

parameterOptions.text: Urine output and color (Assess for hemoglobinuria)
Frequent vital signs (Checking for worsening hypotension/tachycardia)
Presence of a maculopapular rash on the trunk
Lung sounds for new onset of crackles

rationale.correct: Acute Hemolytic Reaction (c2) is a life-threatening event typically caused by ABO incompatibility. The client's symptoms, including lower back (flank) pain, hypotension, tachycardia, fever, and dark-red/tea-colored urine, strongly suggest this type of reaction. Lower back pain is a hallmark early sign caused by hemoglobin clogging the renal tubules. The nurse must immediately disconnect the blood and maintain the IV line with a new line of 0.9% normal saline (a1) to support blood pressure and renal perfusion. Collecting a urine specimen (a2) to assess for red blood cells/hemoglobin is essential for confirming the diagnosis. Frequent vital sign monitoring (p2) and urine output/color monitoring (p1) are critical to assess the patient's response to the reaction and guide further interventions. The goal is to maintain adequate blood pressure and monitor kidney function.
clinicalPearls: Low back pain during a transfusion is a key indicator of an acute hemolytic reaction.
Never flush the IV line that was used for the blood transfusion, as this could push more of the incompatible blood into the patient.
The blood unit and all associated tubing MUST be sent back to the blood bank for investigation.

questionTrap.trap: Slowing the blood infusion rate instead of stopping it.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: There is no 'safe' infusion rate for an incompatible blood unit. If a hemolytic reaction is suspected, the transfusion must be stopped immediately and permanently to prevent further harm.
